text:
- Hello, everyone.
I am Baskar Sridharan.

I lead all of the AI, ML, and
data processing services in AWS.

I'm pretty excited today
to have Greg from Canva.
I would love Greg to introduce himself.

- Thanks. Hi, I'm Greg.
Nice to be here, Baskar.
- Great to have you, Greg.

Before we start, I would
love to understand,
what's Canva's vision for gen AI,

and how are you thinking
about the overall vision?

- We see generative AI
sort of transforming Canva
from top to bottom, really.

We think it's going to change
visual communication.

We're going to see gen AI
linking the various components

and aspects of Canva together
to really make it easy
for people to communicate visually,

create awesome-looking
designs, and just raise the bar
of the designs that they produce on Canva.
- Since the time Canva got onto AWS,
how have you seen the evolution of Canva?
Can you describe that for us?
- Yeah, sure.

So Canva's always been
quite forward-looking

in terms of our usage of
AI and machine learning,

so we did our first models,
gosh, many years ago now,

primarily in the search
and recommendation space,
so we've been training models on AWS

using various technologies,
EMR, Spark, SageMaker,
Bedrock and that sort of environment,

but we've sort of done
the full transformation.
Our original models
were offline batch recommendation models,
so you would run a daily run

of producing recommendations
to your users,

and then we sort of transitioned
to a real-time world

where people would get
real-time recommendations
and various aspects of personalization,
personalizing Canva itself,

and then we sort of rode
the generative AI wave,

and we added text to image in
Canva, so generating images,

and yeah, now we've got
tools like Magic Write

that are producing content
in multiple languages,
and really, we've got a chat assistant,
and we've sort of done the whole journey,

and we use a lot of AWS
services as we do that.

- One of the things that
are harder for companies

in gen AI space in moving
from prototype to production
is the selection of models.

You have a plethora of
models available now.
We just announced Bedrock Marketplace,
which has 100 plus gen AI models.

This is in addition to the
models that we have on Bedrock
from leading foundational model providers.
How would you think about model selection?
What is the advice that you would give

for other companies trying
to make the same journey
that Canva has made so far?
- Yes, the choice is great,
but it can be a little bit overwhelming

knowing where to start,
and that's a real challenge
that we find teams finding.
They often will default to a model
that they may have heard from another team
or social media or something like that,

so there's a sort of bias
that people have naturally,
so we have to sort of help them understand
that there's sort of public leaderboards

and things like that that
they can look at and leverage,
but really, what we're trying to encourage

and sort of the best practice
that we have these days is,

try your best to compare
models in playgrounds
and do a little bit of vibe checks,

so you sort of try a
few and see what works.

Come chat to some of the
sort of experts maybe at AWS
or my team, and then the really good thing
is to sort of have an evaluation suite

that gives you concrete
metrics on what good looks like

and how your performance
characteristics are performing
with the various models, but yeah.

Another thing that helps a
lot is an abstraction layer
between your code and the model backends,

like through Bedrock, so the
Converse API is an example

of something that you
provide that really helps,
you can have a configuration parameter
to swap out from 3.5 Sonnet to 3.5 Haiku,
and then you can kind of compare results,
so in the early stages,
we recommend just having a few examples,
having a play in the playground,
sort of getting your vibe checks,

just so that you kinda
know what family of models

that you might wanna look
at, and then as you progress
through the development life cycle,
it gets a bit more rigorous,
and you might have evaluation suites,
and you can see real metrics

and you can make more hard
cost-accuracy trade-offs.

Now, coming back and
rewinding to the days

when you were prototyping
these gen AI applications
to where you are now into production,
this journey from prototype to production
is not an easy one.
Gartner predicts that 30% of the projects
in prototyping phase fail,
and the remaining get into production.
What is your advice for companies
who want to move from gen AI applications
that are actually in prototype phase
and move them into production?

I call the prototyping
phase the act one of gen AI,
the production is the act two,
so how do you get from act one to act two?
- I think we're all still learning,
if I'm completely honest,
but yes, it's actually very challenging.

It's actually, the gen
AI technology makes it,
it democratizes things quite easily.
so it's actually quite easy

to do very impressive things
sort of from a zero to one,

so you can build an
impressive-looking prototype

that sort of works well on
your laptop or something
and demos well to your team,
and then you think, oh, we're ready to go,

and you might sort of go
too quickly into production,
and then as the real data comes through,
you might get out-of-distribution inputs

and the model behavior is
not what you expected at all,

so that's challenging, so you
need observability on that,
and the other thing is,

if you're not really knowing
what metrics you're measuring,

so you might just go
eagerly go into production,
and then you're actually not sure
on what good necessarily looks like
and you haven't thought about that yet,

and you may have chosen
the incorrect model

for your use case, or
your prompt engineering
may not be good enough or appropriate,

so there's a lot of things
that you need to think about.
So we we're still learning.
We're dipping our toes into phase two.
We do have live features in production,

and I think evaluation
suites really help us.

Canva's got a lot of great
observability tooling,
fortunately, across our product.

We've got a robust A/B
testing system as well
that can help this area,

so you can use A/B testing
as a bit of a crutch
until you get robust evaluation suites,
maybe with LLM judges
so that you can do human-like evaluation,
but if you're unable to get there soon,

a reasonable shortcut might
be A/B testing in production

so you can compare two
variants of your system.

So I think this phase two, this
act two, as you talk about,

is the area where real investment
is happening these days,

and LLM ops tooling and
evaluation suites and guardrails
and the best practices,

we're sort of still
learning them all together,
so it's difficult.
It's even difficult for us at Canva,
but I think my recommendation would be,

if you can do anything,
do evaluation suites.

- That's awesome advice,
because when you look
at taking these gen AI applications
and putting them into production at scale,

you not only want to look
at models, like you said,

of course, the cost of
inference also matters,
but then there is the whole data,
which includes observability,

and you can only improve
things that you observe.
and then there is the guardrails
and the trust piece that you spoke about,

the guardrails that
consumers use for making sure
that they can instill trust in their users

and their customers, so I think
all four are pretty critical
to get to act two of gen AI, I think.

- Absolutely, and then it also
gets even more complicated,
because for each component that you have
that might be generative or agentic,
even if they're performing at 99%,
once you start getting combinations
of these systems interacting,
the sort of cascading errors can be great,
so it's really key to have observability

between all of these things
and being able to observe
and evaluate your overall system,
not just individual pieces,

so you have to be able to
look at multiple levels

of your system to
understand what's going on,
and you can build incredible things,
but as you start composing these things,
the behavior can be a bit challenging
to keep eyes on, so it's very important

to have sort of this
observability as you speak of,

and an evaluation suite that
can help you to make sure

that the overall system
is performing as expected.

- I think you also touched upon
something interesting, too,

Greg, which is going
into act two of gen AI,
into production, also requires the ability

to take a complex workflow
and then decompose them
into smaller, agentic workflows,

and then being able to have
an orchestrating agent,

so to speak, that can put these
agentic workflows together
to achieve the complex workflow.
- Exactly, yes.
- And this is one thing that we have heard

from a bunch of our customers,
and one of the reasons

why we launched Bedrock's
multi-agent collaboration

for precisely this reason,
which is to help customers get
to production with complex workflows

by decomposing them into
smaller, simpler ones.

- Yes, exactly. That's exactly
the kind of thing you need.

You need a framework that helps
you coordinate these things

and be able to evaluate the
whole agent as a workflow.

- So Greg, when we speak
about moving from act one,

which is prototyping,
to act two, production,
getting trust and responsibility right

in these gen AI applications
is extremely critical.

We definitely understand
the criticality of it.
We have heard from customers like you

that they wanted the guardrails
to be one of the key tools
in implementing responsible AI and trust.

How, from your experience
on how you have dealt

with moving, from Canva, from
prototyping to production,

what are your thoughts
on trust, responsible AI,

and what other companies
should be looking at
when they move into production

so that they can instill trust
in their users and customers?

- Absolutely, yes. Canva takes
trust incredibly seriously.

Our product is used at school
and education facilities,
so it's something that you can't skimp on,

and it's definitely tempting
to maybe skimp on this

in the prototyping phase,
and you actually sort of need
to build it in from the beginning,

so Canvas spends a lot of
time with moderation systems,

so we use AWS Rekognition
for a lot of that

as well as custom models
that we have on our side.

Our platform processes,
audio, video, textual content,
so we've got a lot of different modalities
of data that we need to moderate,
and also, out-of-range inputs and outputs,
so having things like guardrails in place

and wrapping trust around
your systems is key,
and it's fantastic that Bedrock Guardrails
is sort of there from the beginning,
so it does make it a lot easier

to think about that from
the prototyping phase
so that when you go into production,

you've got guardrails
in place to make sure
that not only you reduce hallucinations,

but also to make sure
that unsavory content
isn't presented to users,

and you've got inputs
that you need to moderate,

and you've also got outputs
that you need to moderate,
so it's something that you definitely want
to spend a bit of time on,
right from the beginning if you can.

- Where do you think we
are headed with gen AI
in the next three to five years?

- I think we're going
to see it become part

of the regular lifecycle
in almost every product.
It's going to touch every part of what we do.
It's part of our engineering workflow,

the software development
lifecycle and the tooling,
so tools like Q Developer and that,
so it's right there in your IDE,

so the engineers are
going to get more familiar

with these tooling, and not
only necessarily AI specialists,

but it's going to become
democratized for everybody.

We're going to be developing
these best practices,
like you talked about, in phase two,
and these evaluation suites
might become far more commonplace,

and they need to become
far more commonplace,

just as unit testing is
commonplace these days.

The equivalent is possibly
an evaluation suite,
so it's going to be almost everywhere.
I think our products are going to be composed
of traditional software code,
but a lot of these intelligent agents
that can coordinate and orchestrate
in very intelligent ways,

and it's going to make our
systems more human, I think.

- I agree, and I think especially
with the inflection point

that we are in today, where
everything with gen AI
is done in a very compressed timeline,
we have to be able to use tools

that actually help us develop
these gen AI applications

in a much more compressed
timeline, and clearly,

decomposing them into agents
and agentic workflows, I think,

it’s going to be very critical to
get to scale in production.

- Yeah, I think it sort
of rhymes with what we did
with monoliths to microservices,

might be sort of these
agents and workflows
and unit tests to make sure that your code

is performing as necessary
and evaluation suites

to make sure that your AI
is performing as necessary,
so it rhymes, and I think it's probably
going to move that direction.

- Absolutely. Thank you so
much for your time, Greg.
Really appreciate you spending time,

and thank you very much
for the candid conversation
on how other companies can move
from prototype to production.
We love having you as our AWS customer,
we love having you as Bedrock customer,
and I'm definitely looking forward
to having feedback from you

on all of the great Bedrock
launches that we have had.
- Thank you so much.

Looking forward to working
more closely in future.
